title: 110_hr2956
content: The Act may be cited as the "Responsible Redeployment from Iraq Act". The Congress expresses its sense. The Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Iraq Resolution of 2002 authorized the President to use the Armed Forces to defend the national security of the United States against the threat posed by the Government of Iraq at that time. However, the Government of Iraq in power at that time has been removed, and the current Government of Iraq does not pose a threat to the United States or its interests. The Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Iraq Resolution of 2002 allowed the President to use the Armed Forces to protect the US from the threat posed by the Government of Iraq. However, the current Government of Iraq no longer poses a threat to the US or its interests. After over four years of efforts by the Armed Forces and civilians, Iraq's future is now the responsibility of its government. The text chunk states the requirement to reduce the number of armed forces in Iraq and transition to a limited presence of the armed forces in Iraq. The Secretary of Defense is mandated to start reducing the number of Armed Forces in Iraq within 120 days of the enactment of the Act, completing the transition to a limited presence by April 1, 2008. This reduction and transition must be done safely and orderly, with a focus on protecting the redeployed forces. It is part of a broader strategy for the United States. The comprehensive United States strategy for Iraq, as required by the Act, will include further implementation measures. SEC. 4. COMPREHENSIVE UNITED STATES STRATEGY FOR IRAQ. The President must provide a comprehensive United States strategy for Iraq by January 1, 2008, including discussions on national security interests and force levels needed after April 1, 2008. The President must justify the missions of the Armed Forces, including projected number of forces, annual cost, and duration. This justification must address the necessity of missions such as protecting diplomatic facilities and citizens, serving in diplomatic roles, and disrupting threats. The President must provide updates every 90 days on the strategy for Iraq, including actions against al-Qaeda, training Iraqi Security Forces, and diplomatic initiatives with allies for stability. The strategy and updates must be unclassified but may include a classified annex if needed.
